segments.text: But about, I guess, I would say a large part of the essential observations, measurements from these periods.
Ewing also contributed basically two things.
One was his hypothesis that the mid-ocean ridge was a continuous phenomenon throughout all the oceans.
and his idea, his claim that there was a crack down the middle of it, which was being filled with volcanic material.
The other major observation he made was the Ecclesiastical Plains.
Now, you once suggested too, or at least I read and assumed you had suggested, that the oceans are the ultimate receptacle of the waste of land.
Okay.
Does that also apply to radioactive waste?
Twice you've mentioned that in the course of the interview yesterday.
Did I?
Mm-hmm.
You said that twice you were explaining that on bombs and waste as they were being involved and they're coming off the Apto.
Oh, yeah.
That was part of our... What we were interested in there was not...

disposal of those things but what happened what happened to them and and then later on yesterday also you mentioned the fact that that nuclear energy uh worries now a lot of people and i assume by that too you were speaking of disposal of waste of nuclear energy well i'm speaking of several things there one of them is the danger of accidents nuclear reactor another is the disposal of the ways which is sometimes called the faustian bargain
We're not going to be here for a long, long time.
Maybe we'll outlast our civilization.
If so, you're putting an awful burden on future generations.
The third is the problem of what's called the safeguard problem, the problem of plutonium, which is made in reactors and can be used to make, fairly easily used to make atomic weapons.
The one part of that that
that you're asking me now.
Is it possible to dispose of radioactive waste?
Walter Monk is engaged in this.
He's just beginning a study of this.
And he thinks it is possible, essentially by burying them in bottom sediments in such a way that
The heat produced by the radioactivity can get out, but the radioactivity can't get out.
Whether that's possible or not, I don't know.
That's always been a problem with these kind of things, that the fission products are so high radioactive and the absorption of the radioactive radiation produces heat.
And it produces a lot of heat.
You've got to find a way to get rid of that heat and retain the radioactive material.
Keep the radioactivity away from hurting anybody or anything.
Those are sort of incompatible objectives.
You have to keep the radioactivity enclosed in something that will absorb all the radioactivity.
like a big lead box.
That big lead box is also a very poor conductor of heat.
So the thing tends to get awfully hot.

But it may very well be that in the long run, we'll come to the ocean as an ocean bottom sediment in an undisturbed area as a means of disposing of radioactive waves as an alternative to the present favorite of the atomic.
energy people, which is salt, old salt mines.
Of course, the other alternative is not to have too many nuclear reactors.
That, I must say, I'm in favor of not having the darn thing.
I now feel that solar energy is a much more rational alternative of all of my sources of energy.
One of the great resources of the ocean is not generally appreciated is the fact that it is a great hole in the ground, a way to get rid of a lot of garbage that human beings produce.
And much of the garbage that you can dump into the ocean is actually beneficial.
For example, if you dump nutrients like phosphate and nitrate into the ocean,
that may actually encourage the growth of organisms that we like to eat, like fish and marine invertebrates.
It's not at all a one-way proposition.
These guys that say you can't pollute the ocean at all, I think, are just really not thinking very clearly.
The ocean's always been polluted by human activities, and if we do it right, we're not going to hurt it.
We may help it.
On the other hand, there's some things that we may be putting in that are harmful, some trace materials, some poisonous chemicals.
For a while, it was thought that DDT was one of these things that might accumulate at the surface of the ocean.
But it's soluble in oil.
And that that would interfere with the photosynthesis of plankton, and thereby maybe do something to the fish body.
to the fish production.
It seems that DDT doesn't accumulate near the surface very much.
It's not clear what does happen to it.
But one can think of things like that that might be harmful to the plankton organisms and to the fish, certainly.
In shallow waters and in semi-enclosed waters, you can do all sorts of mind-building, like the Minamoto disease in Japan, which is too much metal mercury in shallow water.
It got into the fish and into people and had very serious health effects.
And you also have problems with sewage sludge, which settles to the bottom and seems to create an environment that very few creatures can live in.
It changes the ecology from the various kinds of wide variety of invertebrates to a small number of rather disgusting invertebrates like worms.
Do you think there ought to be some sort of
of a beginning on ways to control the waste dumping in the ocean?
Would you designate a national problem that should have national priorities?
Well, we are doing it.
Too much, I think.
I think it's always a good idea to know what you're doing.
It's a good idea to look at these outfalls, these waste outfalls.
see what happens to the material and whether it's beneficial or harmful.
But I'm not really, I'm not at all in agreement with Cousteau who says we're killing the ocean.
I don't really think we are killing the ocean.
You ought to talk to John Isaacs about that.
Now, I have another quote that I'd like for you to comment on.
You suggested one time in
and some things that you'd written, that scientists should be involved in politics.
Do you still believe that scientists should be more or less active politically?
Well, when I said involved with politics, I don't think I meant that they should be politicians.
Oh, no.
I assumed you meant to influence, as a matter of fact, political decisions.
I think that politicians and scientists have got to learn how to work together.
I wrote my presidential address at AAAS,
was called a politician in the sciences.
Did you see that?
There's really nothing that I can say that I didn't say there.
But I meant every word of that.
And I basically mean that our world is changing so rapidly because of changing technology and increasing knowledge.
It's very complex effects in terms of population growth, resource depletion, changes of ways of life and social changes that result from those changes in the ways of life, like urbanization.
But politicians need to have
as good an understanding as possible as they can of what their options are and what the probabilities are.
The difficulty here is that politicians and scientists are different kinds of people.
And they're quite different in many important respects.
But the fundamental difference is that the politician always has to act.
He has to make a decision regardless of whether it's
based on knowledge or just based on an intuition or a hunch or a gamble.
You've got to do something.
Not doing anything is really the same as doing something in many cases.
The result of this necessity to act and the lack of sufficient information to act on is that politicians always make short-range decisions.
And they try to leave it.
future options open as much as they can.
The only thing they can do.
That's reinforced in the democratic society by the fact that the poor bachelors have to run for election every two years.
So that some people say that infinity to a politician is the election after the next one.
But it's true of all politicians, even if they're dictators or have some kind of a legitimacy not based on election.
just because of the nature of the problem that they face.
Whereas a scientist never wants to act.
He always wants to find out more before acting.
And he always feels that he doesn't know enough to be able to make a positive statement.
Well, the way to get around this, I think, is that politicians and scientists both
have to learn to think more in statistical terms, in terms of probabilities, in ranges of probabilities.
Take a simple case.
What's the population of the United States going to be in the year 2000?
Well, the probability is that, let's say, 50% that it'll be 230 million people, plus or minus 5 million.
The probability is maybe 20% that it'll
somewhere between 240 and 220 million people.
Probability is maybe 10%.
It'll be somewhere between 245 and 210 million people, and so forth.
And one has to prepare for this range of probabilities as best one can, not saying
Not saying we're going to plan for 230 million people, plus or minus .
But that is the most likely thing to do.
So we want to put most of our effort into preparing for that.
Less effort, but some effort into preparing for more or less, in accordance with our range of probabilities.
And demographers have to learn to make their forecasts or their projections in terms of probabilities.
But meteorologists have already learned this.
Meteorologists say that the chances are 20% it's going to rain tomorrow, or they're 80%.
Well, it never says 100% chance it's going to rain tomorrow, or zero chance it's going to rain tomorrow.
But everybody who's concerned about the weather learns to act on these probabilities.
And you try to take out insurance against the unlikely event occurring.
some kind of insurance, either monetary insurance or alternate plans or something.
Going on a picnic, you usually have to have an alternate plan, because you're dealing with probabilities.
Unless you're .
He's dead now, unfortunately.
But the other thing that politicians and what scientists need to learn in order to work together
is to understand how these two different groups of people think.
Politicians like to use an adversary procedure, because they're mostly lawyers.
Scientists take a very dim view of adversary procedures.
They much prefer committee discussion, in which you pound out a kind of a consensus or compromise position, but not
You don't simply present the argument on both sides and leave it to the politician to decide between those two sides.
And both modes of operation have their place and their value, but they're different methods.
Alvin Weinberg has talked about this a good deal, what he calls trans-scientific problems and trans-scientific problems.
Transcience problems involve values that are not scientific.
What you like, what you dislike, what you want, what you don't want, what you think is moral and what you think is immoral.
None of these are scientific questions.
You can't really argue about a scientific question, but you can argue about values.
And the reason you can argue about values is that values are always in conflict, and you therefore have to analyze or to...
to try to give relative weights to different values.
You do this by argument.
Science really is not an arguable subject.
It's a subject which you either know or you don't know.
Most of the time you don't know, but you do know some.
The whole business of technology assessment is a good example of the way in which scientists
Technologists and politicians need to interact.
Another of them deals with policy for science.
The politicians need to be convinced that science operates in a somewhat different way than they're used to.
You can't go out and say, I'm going to make a discovery.
I'm going to discover how to cure cancer.
And maybe the best way to cure cancer is not to work on cancer at all.
to work on the basic biology of the metabolism and the reproduction of cell reproduction.
And this is hard for the politician to get through his head.
He always is liable to say, what have you done for me lately?
Well, you can't say what you've done for him lately.
You've changed the world over the course of 100 years.
But you don't know quite what's going to happen next.
And this is the essence of scientific approach, very unsatisfactory to the politician, and vice versa.
But these are all barriers and difficulties, constraints, in the way of scientists and politicians working together.
It doesn't mean there's any less need for them to work together.
Well, all of this you'll learn.
I'm just saying, I'm just repeating what I said in that residential address.
But you still essentially agree with that, you don't?
Oh, sure.
You've not changed your mind at all, okay.
That was only a couple of years ago.
People's minds change quickly, believe me.
In 1958, you said the oceanography was far behind land sciences.
Would you still agree with that?
Do you think in the last 18 years that that has changed?
Oh, Athelstan Steelhouse used to put it pretty well.
He said, we don't even know more about the moon's backside than we are about the ocean's bottom.
I don't know.
The ocean is a very much more difficult place to find out about than the land is.
On the other hand,

I guess I ask myself about the problems of land science and ocean science that are more or less related to each other, namely the ecological problems, the problems of climate and weather, the problems of geological processes on land and in the sea, the theological and geophysical processes.
and consider the relative importance of the two.
For example, food production is almost entirely a land science, only to a minor extent an ocean science.
I guess with my broader perspective about agriculture and about food production and about the environment, which is, again,
For most people, a land environment.
I would say that on the problems that are important to people, the practical problem that affect people's lives in fundamental ways, the land signs are pretty backward, too.
We have no idea how to predict climate.
We can't predict weather more than about
four or five days in advance.
We don't really understand how ecosystems work on land any more than we do in the ocean.
We don't know what we're doing to the environment on the land in many fundamental and important ways.
So I guess it's compared to their odious in that case.
In both areas, our ignorance is too large, too great.
Well, the next two questions I have consider both of those areas I have listed on my question to ask you.
Both hazard, as a matter of fact, a scientific guess.
What do you suppose the development of the oceans in the immediate future, let's say, define the immediate future of the next 50 years will be?
Will we concentrate more on mineral resources, food resources, or will we continue in this area of exploration of the oceans?
I don't think we'll continue the exploration for a variety of reasons.
One reason is the law of the sea conference is going to make it difficult.
The other reason is that we've probably done most of the things, not everything, but most of the things we can with the tools we have and the understanding we have.
What we need now is to get more understanding of ocean processes.
For example, what is the size of the circulation cells in the ocean?
It looks as if they're relatively small compared to, let's say, the Hadley cells in the atmosphere, that you can deal with most motions in the ocean on a scale of a couple hundred miles.
These big eddies in the Gulf Stream and the Kuroshio are not the size of the planetary eddies in the atmosphere.
They have a different scale, and we don't really understand that scale.

We need to be able to do as Walter Munk is thinking of doing to make measurements, integrative measurements, measurements which tell you what the average conditions are over, say, a 50-mile square, 50 miles on the side.
And one way to do that is to use acoustics, underwater acoustics, statistics of underwater acoustics.
Always in the past, we've made spot measurements in the ocean, either vertical series or a series of horizontal points, usually a lot of vertical series.
But the distances between those vertical series are so large,
And the intervals in time are so great that the results are very unsatisfactory.
We need to be able to measure the state of the ocean all over, over a large piece of it, within a very short time.
You can't do this by the standard oceanographic technique of measuring, of taking oceanographic stations.
Nor can you do it from a satellite.
The satellite can't see below the surface for a few meters.
You may be able to do it with a great many buoys, but that's certainly a hard way to do it.
Possibly the best way to do it would be with integrating measurements.
You have two buoys which measure the sound velocity and the sound scattering and the sound absorption.
and the refraction of rays on a continuing basis, which give you an average condition on the line between the two buoys, in the area between the two buoys, or between two ships, something like that.
In other words, we need to be able to get more meaningful measurements with fewer
with fewer observing points.

And until we're able to do that, in other words, until we're able to develop a new set of tools, a new set of instruments for exploration, I think we might very well be running out our string on exploration with the present tools.
And of course, the third reason is
that the people are much more concerned now about the resources of the ocean than they used to be.
Looks like we're coming close to the limit of how many fish we can catch.

We need to understand the ecology of fishes, and I mean the ecology, not the life history or the migrations of single species, but how fishes live in their environment with other organisms much better than we do.
We need to understand the
the location and the means of recovery, potential reservoirs of oil in the near shore zone within 200 miles of shore.
We probably need to know more about the distribution and content of the manganese nodules in the deep sea.
We need to know more about coastal engineering and about the problems of ports, harbors, and navigation as ocean traffic builds up.
The amount of overseas trade is now at a level that nobody even imagined 20 years ago.
The big bulk carriers represented by various kinds of hazards, they're so hard to maneuver.
Need perhaps a new system for handling those things.
Much perhaps something like we handle airplanes.
Rigorously control the position at all times.
I would guess that, I'm not necessarily saying I'm in favor of this,
I would think it's likely that ocean engineering and applied ocean science are going to be more prominent and fundamental scientific research less prominent over the next 50 years.
I say this myself with some unhappiness because I think it's an awful lot of fun to find out things.
Not to use what you find out.
One of the things that we may be doing in the future is building large floating installations in the high and the open ocean.
Maybe cities in the sea.
Maybe nuclear reactors in the sea.
That seems very likely.
Maybe big pleasure domes offshore.
And this may be particularly true in some crowded parts of the world, like Java, for example.
Maybe you just have to extend the land area of Java by putting a lot of it on the ocean.
And maybe this could even happen in some of the other megalopolises that are near the seacoast, like the Boston or the Portsmouth to Richmond megalopolis off the east coast.
I think it's much more likely to happen off Java than it is off the East Coast.
But our population looks like it was stabilized.
There may be other reasons for putting installations offshore.
That's a big engineering, a whole host of engineering problems involved in doing that.
Guys like Bill Nirenberg are interested in getting energy out of the ocean.
For example, possibly taking advantage of the temperature gradient between the surface and the deep water.
Maybe getting wave energy, which is a form of wind energy, but more concentrated than wind energy.
you can concentrate the energy from a large area and a small area because of the fact that waves lose very little energy as they propagate across the ocean.
That may be a useful thing to look at.
Maybe you can use marine organisms like kelp and other seaweeds as a source of energy, turning them into alcohol or methane or something like that.
